response: narrative=Dennis Mason was last seen by his friend, David Law, at a local study group. Earlier in the day, Dennis had been to a court appearance regarding his foster situation. After the court, he was reportedly upset and withdrawn. Later, Dennis went missing from his home on Greengairs Road, raising concerns among his well-wishers. His friend, concerned by his absence, checked usual places like the bathroom and next to a neighborhood well, but to no avail. After several days of searching, the police traced Dennis to a safe location at East Mains Holdings. Factors contributing to his disappearance seemed linked to the stress surrounding his court appearance.

narrative=Dennis Mason was last seen in the bathroom of his home at 200 Dunkeld Road, PH1 3GH, shortly after a brief court appearance. Despite his young age, witnesses reported that Dennis had become increasingly withdrawn following that event. Irene, a close friend of the family's, noticed Dennis seemed particularly agitated but thought he was merely tired. Later, the family realized he was no longer in the house. After searching nearby areas, Irene alerted authorities, expressing concerns following his recent behavioral changes. The search extended to a nearby public park where Dennis often played but yielded no results. Fortunately, he was traced at a relative's house, unharmed, later that day, having walked there unnoticed.
narrative=Dennis Mason was last seen active on social media before vanishing from 312 Greengairs Road. Friend Leonard mentioned he was absent after a court appearance.

narrative=Dennis Mason, a 7-year-old child residing with his foster family at 312 Greengairs Road, Greengairs, was reported missing after a court appearance. Despite being active on social media before vanishing, he did not show any signs of unusual behavior. On the day of his disappearance, Dennis was last seen near a public park close to his home, where he often played with friends. Concerns were raised when he failed to return home, prompting a search by his foster father and friends in familiar areas, including a well and a public bathroom in the vicinity. After an extensive search, Dennis was eventually found safe and unharmed at home by his family.
narrative=Dennis vanished from 23 Haddow Grove after being active on social media post-court with David Law.

narrative=Dennis Mason, an 8-year-old boy, was last seen leaving a study group in the local public park. He had been spending the afternoon with his friend who recalled Dennis mentioning needing to quickly visit the bathroom. When he did not return, a search ensued. His foster mother, worried, contacted authorities. The park was thoroughly searched by both friends and colleagues, including Maureen Bennett. Eventually, Dennis was traced back to his home, unharmed, after an extensive search effort coordinated by park staff and local authorities.

narrative=Dennis Mason went missing from his home at 312 Greengairs Road, Greengairs, a low-risk incident initially. Before vanishing, Dennis, known for his active presence on social media, disappeared shortly after a court appearance relating to his foster case. There was mention of his friend visiting him at his home, 23 Haddow Grove, Burntisland. Dennis was known to express his apprehension surrounding the proceedings to his friend. His colleague - Mohammad Rees, noted Dennis often shared updates online. Despite being only eight years old, his digital footprint and apprehension were notable. Dennis was eventually traced by staff to Rannes Street, Insch, suggesting he might have sought familiarity during his brief disappearance.

A search was launched after the initial hours of his disappearance. His friend reported seeing Dennis near a neighbor's bathroom before his disappearance, and a colleague of his foster parent mentioned him expressing curiosity about the local well. Debra Thomas, a neighbor, recalled noticing a child of his description near the pier where a small boat was moored. narrative=Dennis Mason was last seen at his home, 312 Greengairs Road, posting actively on social media. Later, he was reportedly heading to join a study group at the library. Concerns grew when his colleague, Mohammad Rees, found Dennis's phone abandoned in a bathroom at the library. Goings-on in a public park near a well where Dennis was last conspicuously active raised suspicions. Authorities traced Dennis to a medical facility on Hospital Street, Perth, where he was found safe.

narrative=Dennis Mason, aged 11, was reported missing from his home at 312 Greengairs Road. Known to be active on social media before vanishing, his disappearance was initially concerning to his friends and colleagues who noted sudden inactivity online. Investigations revealed that Dennis last communicated through a social media application, hinting at plans to explore a nearby well, a location often featured in his posts. The search intensified after no further updates from Dennis. Tracked down by police four days later at an address in Upper Largo, concerns for his safety were addressed. It was later understood that Dennis, seeking refuge and adventure, ventured beyond known areas, ultimately leading to his safe recovery.

narrative=Dennis Mason, an 11-year-old boy, vanished from his home at 312 Greengairs Road, Greengairs, ML6 7TQ. Before disappearing, he had been active on social media, engaging frequently with friends. Following his last court appearance concerning his foster case, Dennis was last seen at home. Reports indicate he briefly went to check a suspicious noise near the bathroom. In the ensuing hours, his whereabouts became unknown. Irene, a family friend, noted that Dennis seemed unusually quiet on the day prior. Efforts to locate him intensified when Ronald Hughes, a colleague of the foster family, discovered his phone abandoned suspiciously near an uncovered well on the property. Dennis was eventually traced to Phoines Estate, Newtonmore, by police, ending the frantic search.

narrative=Dennis Mason was last seen after a court appearance, a situation that raised concerns due to his foster care status. Following the court event, Dennis was noted missing from the library located at 23 Haddow Grove, Burntisland. Despite immediate efforts to locate him, he remained missing for several days. It wasn't until a colleague from the library mentioned that Dennis often frequented nearby public parks that attention was directed there. Acting on this information, a member of the public found Dennis safe at 312 Greengairs Road, Greengairs. Dennis's disappearance is suspected to be linked to feelings of overwhelm and stress following his court appearance, which prompted him to seek solitude.
